title: ArduRoller Chassis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are the laser cutting plans for the chassis for my ArduRoller balance bot. Specs:
Chassis: laser cut 2.7mm bamboo ply (Ponoko); various M2.5 machine screws from Amazon; Instamorph low-melt-point thermoplastic to fill in the gaps.
Brains: 1 x Arduino Uno
Motor driver: 1 x Sparkfun Ardumoto
Motors: Sparkfun 2 x 24:1 gearmotor
Wheels: 1 set Sparkfun 70mm -- repaired with Instamorph after they cracked around the axle
Gyro: 1 x ADXRS613 (Sparkfun breakout) mounted at the axis of rotation
Accelerometer: 1 x ADXL203CE (Sparkfun breakout) mounted at the axis of rotation
Batteries: 2 x 3.7V Li-poly 850MAh (Sparkfun) I've shared the code and assets at github.com/fasaxc/ArduRoller. Video is at www.flickr.com/photos/fasaxc/5944650602/
I've published an instructable at http://www.instructables.com/id/ArduRoller-balance-bot/.

author: Nr5Alive

title: Ultimaker E3Dv5 mount with Tilt z-probe

description.text:
This is my version for an Ultimaker E3D mount. It features a retractable z-probe, which works together with a special part fixed to the construction platform chassis.

There is some Marlin code needed to make it work, I enclose it here.

Extra parts needed:

  • 4x LM6UU linear bearings
  • 2x M3x25 screws
  • 1x M3x10 screw
  • 3x M3 nuts
  • 4x M3 washers
  • 1x microswitch (6,60mm between holes) (may fit bigger ones, just drill where needed)
  • 2x M2x15 screws for the microswitch
  • 1x 3mmx32mm steel or iron rod (a nail, or a screw, or...)
  • 3x neodimium magnets cylindrical radius4mm x 2mm
  • 2x 30mm fan (and their screws) (may fit bigger fans with included adapter)

The design includes for sure remixes from other parts taken from here and there. Although reworked from scratch, it's mainly based in the design of am001; if you can identify any other influences just tell me, and I'll be editing this and will be happy to add the credits as needed.

Marlin full support is provided via this repository : https://github.com/stratop80/Marlin
Last months RCs also available on demand (free).

Any questions, please post on here.

https://youtu.be/gT0HG91EKto
https://youtu.be/qM5AEIOHtP8

Printer:

i3BOXed

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Some captive nuts and screws may be difficult to insert, sockets need to be thoroughfully cleaned.
Check the fit of screws from the fans before assembling, they are intended to be near M3, but I can't seem to find two identical fans so I use whatever screw suits...
Check the right orientation of magnets before glueing inside their pockets, so they snap cleanly together either in the retracted or deployed position of the zprobe.

You can route the wiring (thermistor, heater, fans and switch) up throgh the tube and secure them with belts, and use a cable sleeve to get a neat finish.

Depending of the final position where the "espera.stl" part is fixed in your chassis, fine adjustements must be set in the configuration.h file in Marlin to make it work, just look for anything commented as "TILT" to check where to tweak.

A handy accessory to always have at hand headphones .
On the web I have always found containers for iPhone's headphones, boxes to absurd prices, supports that don't allow to wrap to wrap the headphones securely.
So I decided to create it myself an accessory that acts as the box but also allows me to wrap the headphones securely. In fact I created so that the winding diameter is large enough not to mar or damage the wire .

The project is still under construction , I would provide it with a sort of cover so as not to drop the headphones and better protect them .

Un comodo accessorio per avere sempre le cuffie a portata di mano.
Sul web ho sempre trovato contenitori per le cuffie dell'iphone, scatole a prezzi assurdi, supporti che non permettono di avvolgere il filo in modo sicuro.
Così ho deciso di creare io stesso un accessorio che funzioni da scatola ma che mi permetta anche di avvolgere le cuffie in modo sicuro. Infatti l'ho creato in modo che il diametro dell'avvolgimento sia abbastanza grande da non far rovinare o danneggiare il filo.

Il progetto è ancora in costruzione, vorrei dotarlo di una sorta di coperchio in modo da non far cadere le cuffie e da proteggerle ulteriormente.

description.text:
These are the plans for my wooden construction set, consisting of rods of various lengths with screw holes and a set of brackets. The brackets use T-slots to hold a captive screw/nut so all the parts can be laser cut. Blogged about here: http://fasaxc.blogspot.com/2011/11/woodbug.html
Make picked it up here: http://blog.makezine.com/archive/2011/11/woodbug-a-community-commons-laser-cut-building-set.html

Laser cut the two panels.  The rods work well in 3mm ply, the brackets a little thicker, say 5-6mm ply.
Assemble into whatever design you please or use to augment another model.  M2 screws and nuts are recommended.  I haven't tried with non-metric screws.

title: Voronoi mesh bunny, with shadow base

description.text:
Uneven bottom did cause others to fail, so I modified this with shadow baseplate. The baseplate follows bunny's shape, so it is hidden but allows bunny to print much easier.

Model is based on Standford Bunny and thus it shouldn't be used commercially.

Main work with bunny was made by raccoo.
http://www.thingiverse.com/raccoo

Printer:

Fabrikator Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

So thin it doesn't matter

Notes:

Test print was my printers max size (80mm) and tip of one ear is so thin it didn't close, but overall good print without supports.

Filament was eSun purple PLA.
This model has so much jumps, that it is likely to cause a lot of tiny stringing. I did find it easier to fix "spider web" thin strings with flighter flame that trying to perfect my print settings.

1. Slice original model
  2. Take screenshot from first few layers.
  3. Trace outline with CAD software (Fusion 360)
  4. Extrude few millimeters.
  5. Export to stl
  6. Combine with the original model using mesh editor. (integrated "3D Builder" from Windows 10)

title: UPDATE: Simple dual fan mount for MK8 direct drive extruder

description.text:
This is a never revision based on my simple fan holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1423957

It is designed to mount two 40mm fans at the extruder to cool down the object. It replaces one of the spacers between the heat sink and the fan on the side.

I printed it as it is in PLA with 0.2mm height, 10% infill and without support. After printing, I drilled the holes for the fans up to 4mm

UPDATE: I uploaded V5, which is the latest and greatest. The fans are now moved a bit to the left to be more aligend with the extruder and give a better and give a more consistend cooling to the part. Over that, I made the holes for the screws bigger so that you don't need to drill them up. So basically, you can now use it directly after printig. There is no picture yet, but you can see the difference in the STLs.

Side note: I printed my holder in PLA, which is not the best choice for a part which is next to the hot end. Acutally, it began to be very soft and deformed during a print (very slow printing speed, large 1st layer, 240deg at hot end for filaflex, fans disabled for 1st layer). Now, I have the fan enabled from start and the problem is gone (and my printing quality has also improved).

print_settings.Notes:: Its better to reduce the infill to 2 or 3 % because then the plaster runs better into the model and it saves a bit of material

description.text:
Nefertiti model inspired by the blog post and Youtube video from RichRep (Richard Horne) http://richrap.blogspot.nl/2016/03/3d-printing-and-finishing-nefertiti.html

I had to cut the model into 11 pieces so it fitted my 3dprinterlab.org standard Prusa i3 (200 X 200 Y 220 Z build space), printed with a 0.4 mm nozzle.

After printing the parts I filled them with plaster and glued them together with epoxy. Then I sanded down the joint and gave it a coat of Zinc primer and sanded down the model very lightly to preserve the 3d printer artifacts. Finally I gave the model 3 coats of golden spray paint.

https://www.facebook.com/3dprinterlab/

author: ritalstyle

description.text:
Mechanical Parts Library currently contains three parts for your projects: Gear, rack, and wheel. There are many customization options for each part. I am planning to extend this library in time. There are comments explaining modules, parameters and even the code itself.

I am open to suggestions for what to include next.

There is a customizer for gears: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1427458

This library is licensed with MIT license, since not listed here, I have chosen LGPL (which is compatible with MIT) from the list. The parts (physical or stl files) you create with this script is your own work and you may use them as you like.

Gear
  • Spur, helix, and double helix (herring bone) gears
  • Customizable pressure angle
  • Cutoff: so gears with 5 teeth possible even with pressure angle 0 (still not a good idea)
  • Uses metric units
  • Semi gears with reinforcing
  • Multiple mounting hole shapes and features
  • Different spacers to reduce material use: polar for equal angular spacing, circles for commonly used circular spacing, linear for equal distance spacing, polar ovals for nice looking spacers.
  • Adjustable details
  • Single polygon gear generation algorithm: no unnecessary operations to slow down rendering
  • Handle
Rack
  • Spur, helix, and double helix (herring bone) tooth
  • Customizable pressure angle
  • Uses metric units
  • Single polygon gear generation algorithm: no unnecessary operations to slow down rendering
  • Adjustable rails for top and bottom
Wheel
  • Multiple mounting hole shapes and features
  • Different spacers to reduce material use: polar for equal angular spacing, circles for commonly used circular spacing, linear for equal distance spacing, polar ovals for nice looking spacers.
  • Adjustable details
  • Chamfered or straight wheel, with a method to reduce or remove overhangs
  • Ability to create bridgeable arms
  • Customizable/optional tracks (only one style is available for now)
  • Handle

• Joints
  • Bevel gears with octoid profile
  • Worm gears
  • Hinge
  • Spiral & hex spacer
  • Propeller
  • Hand crank
  • Pulley
  • Timing belt
  • Z-axis spacer for wheels

author: kike_ton

description.text: This is a 3D printable Carcassonne accessory "meeple" personalised with a little love heart on its chest.  I made it for my girlfriend who has often lamented the lack of a set of purple meeples for the game.
I had mine manufactured using Shapeways.  I exported the file as a CAE from Sketchup and then uploaded to Shapeways with no problem.

comments.text: I wish there was a flat version STL file for this.
comments.author: ScarabCiarog

comments.text: I was originally looking to see if somebody had already created the standard meeples so I could print them for my girlfriend, who has often expressed similar sentiments to yours regarding purple pieces (not to mention the choice to add gray instead of purple in Inns and Cathedrals), but when I found these I knew I had to print the heart version.
comments.author: LawrenceJohnston

comments.text: Hehe, thanks for the comment.  Makes it worthwhile to upload.
comments.author: LawrenceJohnston

comments.text: My first print with PLA on my ToM.  Unfortunately the soft transparent plastic makes the heart almost invisible, but my wife's coming back tomorrow so I have an incentive to try and do better!
comments.author: Typhlosaurus

comments.text: Just saw your comment.  Thanks for stopping by and making something I designed.
comments.author: Typhlosaurus

remixed_from.author: Lanthan
remixed_from.title: Full crossbracing for Prusa simplified Mendel

title: Pan and Tilt HDMIPI Mount with cross bracing

description.text:
Having backed the HDMIPI kickstarter project some time ago finally got around to using it for it's intended purpose to make my mendel more standalone. It has a Pi model B+ 2 inside for a usable raspbian desktop running Pronterface, Slic3r and Octoprint to name a few.

It uses a remake of the excellent http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15606 by Lanthan for additional x-carriage bracing which is a bit poor on a standard Mendel design. Cross braces are made from M6 stock threaded bar and perfectly adequate but take care not to distort the frame on installation.

There is still room for 2 extruders on the top rail but Tricolor users will need to mount the third elsewhere. there are 2 versions of the left hand side brace as one can double as a PCB mount if using a Melzi board

Cubify Design Source included

print_settings.Notes:: There is a 0.25 mm layer of plastic that makes the transition between the 8 holes and their respective shafts. It has to be removed as well.

description.text:
This is a case for the Raspberry Pi 3 B.

This came as a challenge from a friend of mine who wanted a secure case, but did not want the bulge of external screw, like on my previous case series: Safe and Secure Case which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:423216

In this iteration, I decided to use M2.5 socket head screw, so this meant I could use the holes in the motherboard to secure the case in place. Hence, this is the result. The case is 20 mm high and about 2-3 mm thick. This make for a very compact case.

I'll add more top and bottom design upon request.

Enjoy.

Edit 1: Added honeycomb top upon request.
Edit 2: Added 40mm Fan top upon request.

Printer:

Ike:Core

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

80%

Notes:

This case is designed to be printed at 0.25 mm for layer height.

It uses 4 x M2.5 20mm socket head screws to secure the case.

I printed mine at 80% infill.

I only print in PLA, and this case has 0.2 mm 0.25 mm in tolerance, which means, if you ooze too much or are using ABS, think about enlarging the print by 1%.

Also, any brim used, or first layer being squashed a lot, be prepared to use an X-Acto to remove the extra plastic for the screw head and nut traps.

There is a 0.25 mm layer of plastic that makes the transition between the 8 holes and their respective shafts. It has to be removed as well.

This is designed with Fusion 360.

The Fusion 360 source file is included, but remember, Fusion 360 cannot open a local file, you must first upload it to your cloud in order to see/edit it.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed with 7 shells to make sure the teeth were solid. I used a cheap brittle natural PLA on mine, but its holding the cables without snapping. I was pretty light on the infill, but you might want to go a little heavier.

description.text:
Computer cable strain relief. Something to help take the weight of long cables hanging from the back of the computer. I'd hate to snap a USB port off inside, This item will take some of the strain off the cables Slide a cable in where it fits tightly. Optionally you could put a tight nylon wire tie above the insertion point for additional protection. Ok, or a knot if you want to go old-school. There are a variety of slot sizes (2 of each, but you can certainly double-up). Hopefully there's a size for everyone.

The screw holes were a bit small on my print, so I had to drill them out. I've enlarged the holes in the uploaded STL file. I used regular decking screws to attach it.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I printed with 7 shells to make sure the teeth were solid. I used a cheap brittle natural PLA on mine, but its holding the cables without snapping. I was pretty light on the infill, but you might want to go a little heavier.

Previously I used a piece of paper as a diffuser since my printer only has one extruder and printing the lenses separately wasn't working. Then my Son, trying to figure out how it worked, put his finger right through the paper.

So now I've got a 0.5mm thick printed diffuser in there and it's working better. I printed mine in natural PLA with a layer height of 0.2mm and a bottom layer height of 0.3mm, so two layers.

I also printed a plug to put in the back, which I attached with some superglue. That'll hopefully keep him from pulling the electronics out again. :)

Also, I found that some old computer fan screws fit great.

Slowly making it tougher.

title: Retinol binding protein (RBP) from PDB file 1RBP

description.text: Retinol binding protein is a serum (in blood) transporter that binds retinol (vitamin A) for transport through the body. Retinol is a hydrophobic (water-insoluble) molecule, thus requiring a protein transporter. The protein has hydrophobic amino acid sidechains that bind retinol in its interior barrel while the outside surface of the protein is covered with hydrophilic and charged amino acid sidechains making it soluble. In this model, key hydrophobic residues were displayed inside the barrel. The rest of the protein is in "ribbon" view while the retinol is in "spheres" view.

I plan on having high school students print protein models to demonstrate their understanding of protein structure and function. My goal is to use free software with a reasonable learning curve so that this is accessible to my students. UCSF Chimera was used to manipulate the PDB file 1RBP (01_1rbp_in_Chimera.py). Protein is in ribbons, retinol in spheres, residues Tyr90, Met88, Phe77, Phe36, Phe45, Phe135, and Phe137 were displayed as sticks (these are hydrophobic residues with their sidechains lining the interior barrel). I also created artificial "bonds" to hold the retinol in place in the physical model. I also created a second model with the retinol unbound.
  • Open 01_1rbp_in_Chimera.py in UCSF Chimera.
  • "Export scene" and save as .stl file. I saved this as 02_1rbp.stl.
  • Open 02_1rbp.stl in Autodesk Print Utility. Scaled to 300%. Optimized by selecting "Thicken thin regions."
  • "Send to MakerWare."
  • In MakerWare, Raft "on", Supports "on", Infill "10%", shells "4", Layer height "0.2".

title: DIY $42 FPV Goggles for RC Quadcopters or Planes

description.text:
In my opinion the best way to enjoy FPV is with video goggles. Sadly the cheapest FPV goggles out there is around $150. $150 I don't have. So i came up with a solution! A DIY pair you can make for $42! Sure the experience isn't as great as what you would get from a Fatshark or other high end FPV goggles, but its definitely worth the 42 bucks!

The goggles consist of a 4.3 inch LCD screen, Foam board, Ski Goggles, and Duct tape (color)
LCD: http://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-4_3-Inch-LCD-Car-Rearview-Monitor-with-LED-Blacklight-for-Camera-DVD-p-63953.html?p=KX28152008068201507H 15.99
SKI GOGGLES: http://www.banggood.com/WOLFBIKE-Riding-Glasses-Ski-Goggles-Motorcycle-Windproof-Glasses-p-1018141.html?p=KX28152008068201507H ($5.94)
RECEIVER: http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-FPV-5_8G-32CH-Wireless-AV-Receiver-RC832-p-975426.html?p=KX28152008068201507H ($19.99)

Step 1: Parts / Materials
Parts:
4.3 Inch LCD screen - $15.99
(I got mine here)
http://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-4_3-Inch-LCD-Car-Rearview-Monitor-with-LED-Blacklight-for-Camera-DVD-p-63953.html?p=KX28152008068201507H

Ski Goggles or 3D glasses - i got mine from Wm- around $15 Bucks but you can pick this, which is better (save money and material)

1st option http://www.banggood.com/WOLFBIKE-Riding-Glasses-Ski-Goggles-Motorcycle-Windproof-Glasses-p-1018141.html?p=KX28152008068201507H ($5.94)

2nd option (can skip some steps if you buy these) http://www.banggood.com/ColorCross-Virtual-Reality-3D-Video-Glasses-For-46-inch-Smartphones-p-958588.html?p=KX28152008068201507H ($13.99)

3rd option (can skip some steps if you buy these) http://www.banggood.com/Xiaozhai-Z3-BOBOVR-VR-Box-3D-Google-Glasses-Virtual-Reality-Movie-Video-Game-for-46-Inch-Smartphone-p-1020539.html?p=KX28152008068201507H ($14.99)

Materials:
Dollar tree foam board
Hot Glue and glue gun
Duct tape (any color you want)
Tools:
Hobby Knife
Straight edge
Pencil

Step 2: Screen Distance
Determining the distance the screen is from your face is critical!! For everybody the distance may be different depending on the users eyesight.

Place the screen in front of your face and find a distance you like. Then take a ruler and measure how far it is from your nose to the front of the screen. Record the measurement.

In my case i liked 3 1/2 in

Step 3: Constructing the Screen Housing

Start by popping out the lens of the ski goggles. Trace the top part of the goggles onto the foam board, find the middle of the Goggles and draw a straight line out. (Make sure you use a square) From the leading edge of the goggles measure out the distance you want the screen (step 3's measurement) Find the length of the screen and center it on the line(picture 5) Then find the width of the screen and and add that measurement from the line where the screen would sit. Draw another line where the back of the screen would be. (the same length from Picture 5) From the corner of the goggles to the very far line Draw a line with a straight edge.(Picture 8) Do the same on the other side. Make notches on the line that was just drawn. The notches should be 1 cm deep and 1 1/4 inch long, space the two with another inch. Duplicate on the other side and make sure the distance from the corner of the goggles to first notch is the same. (notches may be different depending on the distance you choose the screen to be) Cut the piece out and trace it onto foam board. Cut the piece out.

Sides:
First find the height of the screen and add 1/8 of an inch. Then find the length of the base board. (the tapered side) Make a square with the two measurements that you just acquired.(Don't cut out yet) Lay the base board next to the side and make marks on where the notches are. The notches on the side board should come out NOT in! Cut it out, trace it, and cut that one out.
Step 4: Gluing and Tape
Now glue all the piece together to construct the housing. Add strapping tape or packaging tape on the edges.

Test fit the screen and if there is a gap cut a piece of foam board out and glue it the housing.

Bevel the edges of the housing as in Picture 6

Glue the top of the housing to the goggles. The bottom of the goggles may not fit. I used one of the rounded edges that was cut out previously from the top or bottom base boards. I then removed the paper from the inner side to make it more flexible. Glue it in along with the bottom of the goggles.

Make a notch for your nose if needed

Step 5: Duct Tape and Mounting the Screen
Cover the housing in duct tape for color and to make the inside darker for better Video footage. Stark with the top, then the bottom, and then the sides.

Glue the LCD display in with a bead of glue!

Give it a test!

Step 6: Done!
Now enjoy the feeling of flying like never before!!

Thanks and enjoy with the cheapest FPV googles!

4.3 Inch LCD screen - $15.99

This is final product, you can decorate it however you want.
Now enjoy the feeling of flying like never before!!

remixed_from.author: TakeItAndRun
remixed_from.title: Inner Bevel for abitrary shapes in OpenSCAD

title: Inner Bevel between any (convex) Shape and a Plane In OpenSCAD

description.text:
This is an OpenSCAD module that creates an inner bevel between any (convex) part and a plane at z=h. Please note that the part does not have to be perpendicular to the z-plane. The bevel will be h_bevel high and r_bevel wide. For h_bevel equal to r_bevel the bevel will have circular cross section in the plane(s) perpendicular to the z-plane.
The number of faces of the bevel along its cross section is given by fn_bevel. For fn_bevel=1 this will be a linear bevel. The 'roundness' of the bevel along the z-plane is given by $fn.
This module uses projection() to get the 2d shape of the part at a certain height. This shape is then minkowski()-ed with a circle with the radius of the width of the bevel at this height. In a last step hull() is applied to two layers of consecutive height.
Because of the use of the hull() command the shape of the part has to be convex (concave parts would be filled in from the hull() command).
Because of a limitation of the minkowski() command the part has to be simple: no holes and not comprised out of two disjoint shapes. This thing is inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:135408
from GregFrost. Enjoy! (The .scad-file has no documentation or comments, yet.)

comments.text: Very nice work! I'll be using it profusely in an airplane model!

comments.author: cathalgarvey

description.text:
Shown here is a generic printed axis. I designed and printed this one today to be the Z-axis for a Stereolithographic UV 3d printer I'm making. I will upload more progress about the printer as I make it. This axis seems to work well enough. I used 3/8" steel rods and bushings, because that's what I had laying around. I also used 1/4" 20tpi threaded rod. The SCAD file is generic, so you can change a few variables to make it 1/4 - 8mm rod compatible. I also used piece of plywood as a base.
I built the axis to be 300mm overall length, you can choose any length you'd like. I would recommend using an lm8uu or equivalent for your rod diameter instead of bushings. When you change to lm8uu's or other, you'll need to adjust the slider to fit.

Needed items: 12x 5mm bolts, washers, & nuts
1x 608 bearing
stepper motor
8mm nut
300mm 8mm-threaded rod
2x 300mm 3/8" steel rod.
3/8 ID, 1/2 OD brass bushings (2 or 4)
anything else I forgot to add.

comments.text: I understand the clip and teeth on the block hold one end of the belt but how is the other end held in place, I am so confused! And does it matter what side of the block the tooth extension comes out at? The one I just printed is mirrored from yours im pretty sure... Do you need to print 2 clips? I printed http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1206926 X-Tension_With_Bearing_Block_for_Stock_Bearing.stl......One side has the teeth and the other has a small retangle hole.....As you can tell I am confused, help will be greatly appreciated!
comments.author: JonBAL

comments.text:
One end of the belt hold in teeth on the bearing block (left side of block, if you see from front printer). Second end of the belt you hold in belt-holder (my design or new Heathicus's design). Put a long screw M3 (40mm or more) in hole of belt-holder. Put the belt-holder with screw in square hole of bearing block (right side of block). Put a nut M3 in hexagonal hole (left side block, where tip of screw) and twist a screw.
For tensoin of belt twist a screw. It's a simple.

title: Another parametric customizable stand for my parametric bottle tray

description.text:
This is another customizable, parametric stand for my bottle trays. The advantage of this one over my other design is that it's quicker to print (it takes about 60% less time) The disadvantage is that it takes up a bit more room and may not fit your print bed. By default, the legs are 10mm square so the outside dimensions will be 20mm larger than the inside. If you made a tray which is more than 180mm wide and your print bed is only 200 mm then it won't fit. My other design only added 6mm to the width (with default wall thickness of 3mm).

There isn't much to input, just measure the dimensions (width length and height) of the object that you want to be able to put underneath and add a couple of mm for clearance. Alternatively, measure the size you want the top to be and take off 20mm (or twice whatever size the legs are) which will give you the inside dimensions.

You can change the size of the legs but the default is 10mm and should be fine (and they are hollow to sped up the print time).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Modified RepRapPro Mendel 3 Tricolour

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is a functional object so doesn't need to be printed at fines resolution. I suggest you use the fastest speed and largest layer height you can get away with.

It's just a table with 4 legs, printed upside down. As ever, I've used long meaningful names for the variables and the openscad file is annotated so it should easy to understand and modify if you want to.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7PaWpkqqQwe

This allows you to mount the FatShark TVL600 (or similar) FPV camera so it can be rotated by a servo on the FeeYoung ZX-250 quad frame. The flange is printed 0.2mm wider with a 0.5mm support. Once printed and cooled, you have to twist the flange to break it free. A few twists back-and-forth will loosen it up so it can act as a bearing. title: Collet Holder for Precise Bits (Think & Tinker) Bosch Collet System

description.text:
I love my Precise Bits Collet system from Think & Tinker! It makes my homebuilt CNC (which is built around a Bosch 1617 router) exponentially more useful!

The only problem that I ran into was coming up with a storage solution for these outstanding little collets. If I kept them in their original packaging, they took too long to swap out. If I kept them out, they never had a good "home"; so the ones that weren't currently in use sat out openly in my workspace.

I solved that problem with this little gizmo. Mine uses strong magnets to attach to the side of my CNC router. You may want to attach this using screws instead of magnets. If that's the case, just let me know and I'll modify the design and re-post for you.

All in all, I'm happy with this little gizmo; it's going to help me keep my workspace just a little bit cleaner and speed up my tool changes by a few seconds.

description.text:
Just a very basic holder for Sony Xperia M4.
Ment to be printed in PLA and Ninjaflex or similar soft plastic.

The idea is to make the holder out of PLA and then print the 'sleeves' which will hold the phone with ninjaflex, to reduce vibrations and provide less harsh of a grip.

The bracket is ment for a 1" / 25.5mm bar, commonly found on motorcycles.
You can print thicker sleeves to adjust for smaller bars though.

Hardware needed:
1x m4x30
3x m4x20
2x m4 nuts

Check me out at:
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/MrCrankyfaceProjects
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/mr.crankyface/
3d hubs: https://www.3dhubs.com/malm%C3%B6/hubs/mrcrankyface
Patreon: http://patreon.com/Mrcrankyface

Printer:

Custom CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

description.text:
The BUTTERFLY EGG VASE design is based on the natural structure of actual butterfly eggs possibly laid by Inachis io (European Peacock butterfly).

I recommend printing in translucent filament so that the structure and liquid inside create a better effect. I also recommend you coat the inside with a water-resistant layer to make it watertight.

design: Filip Foltman
photo of eggs: Jay Cossey http://www.photographsfromnature.com/
photo of butterfly: Filip Foltman https://www.instagram.com/foltak/

Notes:

recommended print in translucent filament

print_settings.Notes:: Use some sandpaper around a dowel or a wrench socket and smooth out the inside of A17 so it fits better around the rod.

title: Eclips3D A16 and A17 rod brackets

description.text:
Original parts were designed to be printed vertically. This makes the parts susceptible to cracking along the layer lines. I remade the parts so that they can be printed laying flat with the layer lines parallel to the rods. This should make them a bit stronger and alleviate cracking.

Added files with a little looser tolerances. Rod hole is increased to 10.2mm, M3 nut cutouts are enlarged to 5.8mm.

Printer:

Eclips3D

Resolution:

0.16

Infill:

30 ~ 40%

Notes:

Print with the flat side down rod cutout up, except on the A17 Top part. Use supports on the A17 top if your printer can't handle the overhang. At least 2 shells on the sides and 3~4 on the top and bottom should make these plenty strong. PETg/nylon is also recommended, but PLA should work.

Print 4 of the Bottoms, 3 of the A16 Tops, and 1 of the A17 Top.

Use some sandpaper around a dowel or a wrench socket and smooth out the inside of A17 so it fits better around the rod.

title: Inductive sensor mount for Folger Technologies E3D Direct Drive

description.text:
I use an inductive sensor for bed autolevel but wanted to try this extruder with my new e3d v6. So I mixed this up in openscad. The openscad source is included, but uses the original clamp.stl as an import. You can print it without the integrated clamp and there are two holes provided which can be used to bolt it to the clamp instead.

I've test fitted this but haven't actually used it yet as I'm still getting ready to install the new extruder. As I feared this was a little long for comfort. It's usable as I originally uploaded it but the 2_2 version fixes two major issues I had with the initial design:

  1. The sensor mount hung down a little too low, I was barely able to thread the nut on the bottom of my sensor and once I shrank the support shaft from my original design to bring the sensor closer to the nozzle I was worried about flex in the thinner shaft. Shortening the shaft by 8mm solved both of those concerns.

  2. Pulling the sensor closer to the shaft made it hard to get the top nut on and impossible to fit the lock washer under it. In the 2_2 version I added a cove to the support arm which provides clerance for the nut and washer.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Folger 2020 Prusa i3

No

No

0.24mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

With the front of the clamp and ring against the bed this will print without supports. The holes for the clamp print a little better with support but on my printer the ring comes out the same with or without.

Supports aren't necessary, but if you prefer you can print it with the ring flat on the print bed and supports under the bracket.

description.text: This is a laser cut wood spool holder for M3D Printer. It has a sturdy support bar with teeth that grip the wide uprights to keep them all secure.

Options when building...

I know it's kind of obvious, but I'll fill this part in anyway.

To build, stack and glue 3 of the short handled hooks together, then glue the long handled hooks onto either side. Make sure all pieces line up smoothly.
Glue 3 rectangles together. These are the crossbar supports.
Glue the support near the top between the long handles with anything from 1/4" to 1/2" clearance for the bar itself to slide down between the handles.

Repeat with the other hooks.

Glue the 3 crossbars together. Make sure all pieces line up smoothly.

To use: Just hook the hooks onto your M3D as shown. Insert the crossbar into one or more spools onto the crossbar and position the crossbar onto the handles. Be sure the teeth are downward so as to help loch the whole structure in place.

There's room for 3 spools for storage and easy swapping of filament colors.

Better than 3D.

I was not pleased with the results of the other spool holder designs for the M3D, so I decided to make my own with my laser cutter and some wood. Yes, I do own both. :-/ I'm a gadget geek.

My new YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnnw56J_TeOsF4M_F5pPPJQ The successor to the first R. Maker Ornament. This one is less of a silhouette and has more detail to show of R. Maker. ENJOY!

Print (I recommend totally solid)
Hang
HUZZAH!

I wanted to use up filament odds & ends. So I've printed some simple cubes to make a stress toy to play with whilst waiting for things to print.

You need two ends, and as many middle parts as you would like! String them together with elastic cord (I used 2mm elastic cord (search for "ELASTIC BUNGEE ROPE SHOCK CORD" on eBay for examples))

Ongoing, rather than printing test plain cubes on a new roll of filament, I'm going to print and collect these and add them to the chain.

Top tip: When threading the cubes, add some tape to the end of the cord (Like a shoelace) to make them easier to thread.

As well as the STLs, I've added the openSCAD file and a customizer to adjust the cube & hole dymensions

author: andrewhennessy3455

description.text:
See final update. Do not make this yet. It has a problem.

This is a total remix of the Mostly Printed CNC to use bushing. It also simplifies many of the parts to make it an easier assembly. This is a work in progress and can and will change.

The original designer (Allted) did a awesome job on this and my design should in no way take anything away from his great work. It is merely an alternative for those that want to try it.

To build the unit:

Print 4 corner's (stand upright with supports)
Print 4 roller1's (lay on motor mount. No support)
Print 1 resizedcnccenterforbushings88 (stand upright with supports)
Print 14 endcap's (no support)
Print 1 zaxismotormount231 (no support)
Print 4 feet
Print 1 nutlock

The bars are held in place by drilling holes into to the bars and using a 3mm tap and then screw together will 3mm screws.

This unit works with bunting bearing or bushing if you will. They are 15/16" x 1 1/2" long.
You will need at least six of these. You can find them here: https://www.zoro.com/bunting-bearings-sleeve-bearing-id-1516-l-1-12-pk3-cb151812g3/i/G3982474/

This design also uses nema 23's.

You are also going to need a nema 23 to 5/16" screw coupler. My nema 23 shaft size is 8mm so I am using an 8mm to 8mm coupler and it works well.

You can find it here: http://www.ebay.com/itm/5-16-inch-to-8mm-Set-Screw-Shaft-Coupler-By-Actobotics-Part-625194-/281957727216?hash=item41a5fd7bf0:g:hZQAAOSwT6pVsV4I

Other than these special items all the other hardware for this unit is basically the same as the original design by Allted. You will still need 8 608zz bearings. 8 5/16" screws 2" inches long and 8 5/16 Fender Washers and a bunch of 3mm screws which you can find here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005DZZC4G?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00

Update - 3/20/2016

I am currently in the process of building this thing and when I find things that could make it easier I am modifying them as I go. I will also provide any helpful advice as well.

Update - Added a channel guide for better wire management to the roller unit. No you can hide all the wires coming out of the bars.

Update 3/21/2016 - Added feet to unit and also added an alternative center that has bushing for the tool head at the request of a couple of people. These bushings are not necessary but if you want it all to have bushings here you go.

Just to be clear the file called -
resizedcnccenterforbushings88.STL is without the tool head bushings and the file called
cnccenterforbushingswithtoolbushings.STL is with the bushings. Either one should work fine.

Update 03/22/2016 - Added a lock cap to the nut assemble to prevent nut from sliding up.

Update - I have now tested the x and y axis bushing and they work great. Very smooth.

Update 4/1/2016 - I have now tested the z axis and I am sorry to say it is not going to work as I had hoped. It is way to loose. I need to find some bushing that will fit a little snugger. These are 15/16" and they are very close but they do have a bit of play. I am putting the project on hold to explore another option. Do not make this yet. It does not work. I will post again when I devised a solution to the problem.

title: Hellbender 122 Camera Mount for Lumenier SM-600 / 600tvl Mini FPV cam

description.text:
Fits along the front of the upper plate. The gap should be printed with support and you can use a serrated knife or file to clean it out. This is designed to fit the mic as well. Use zip ties to secure it in place. To keep the camera in place, I've been using electrical tape on the inside of the mount to provide enough friction. If that doesn't end up working, I'll update the file with a way to secure it with a zip tie or something.

Let me know how it fits, I may change the placement of the zip ties because while they work nicely, they're imperfect. The zip tie hole at the base of where the camera sites is a vestigial feature, it works but gets in the way of the camera a bit and puts pressure on the wire.. Use the two in the back and tie it down to the frame using the holes in the frame's top plate.

PS: The print quality is terrible in the photo since my printer is in desperate need of cleaning/calibration. Print should work nicely on you printer.
